Picture this: Youâ€™ve been battling The Bugâ„¢ for hours. Sleepless nights, 100+ Stack Overflow tabs open, your coffee mug judging you for the refill countâ€¦ and then, your team leader walks in. ğŸ˜Œ

You think, Finally! Help has arrived ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸš’ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ”§. The cavalry! The guru of all things code. Surely, the bug doesnâ€™t stand a chance now.
BUT THEN...

Your team leader takes one look at the code, says, â€œHmm, let me try something real quick.â€
And BAM ğŸ’¥ not one, not two, but THREE new bugs magically appear.
â€œOh, uhâ€¦ gotta run to a meeting. Good luck!â€ ğŸ˜³

And just like that, youâ€™re left staring at a disaster zone. Your single bug is now a family of bugs, thriving and happy in your code. ğŸğŸ›

Radhika Gupta, Edelweiss clarified that while hard work is non-negotiable for success, it must be sustainable. â€œHard work is not equal to hours worked. Many of those hours in entry-level careers were pure facetime. Hard work needs to be sustainable for us to do it long enough for compounding to kick in.â€

She criticized inefficiencies in workplace culture that reward appearances over output. â€œMany developed nations work 8â€“4 but ensure those hours are productive. Come in on time, bring your best, and use technology to be effective,â€ she wrote, citing her teamâ€™s use of AI to reduce grunt work.

posts.name:
Startup Pedia
Startup Pedia
posts.content:
On Thursday, the National Restaurant Association of India (NRAI) strongly opposed the leading restaurant aggregators Zomato and Swiggy entering private-label food delivery through their quick-commerce platforms.

The NRAI charged Zomato and Swiggy with leveraging their dominant market positions and access to restaurant data to introduce private-label food products directly or through subsidiaries like Blinkit Bistro and Swiggy Cafe/SNACC.

â€œZomato and Swiggy, originally established as marketplace platforms, are now leveraging their dominant positions and access to restaurant data to venture into private-label food delivery either directly or via their subsidiary,â€ the NRAI disclosed, adding that it raises legal concerns under the Copyright Act and associated laws.

â€œThis strategy not only cannibalises the business of restaurants that rely on these platforms but also raises serious concerns under the Copyright Act and related laws,â€ the association added.

NRAI President and Wow Momo! CEO Sagar Daryani said disapprovingly, â€œWe were always given verbal assurances by the aggregators that they would never resort to private labelling. This is a breach of trust.â€

Moreover, he pointed out the issue of consumer masking, stressing that restaurants do not have access to customer data collected by the aggregators.

The NRAI, representing over five lakh restaurants in India, stated that this move breaches marketplace neutrality and impairs fair competition, creating a significant threat to the survival of restaurants nationwide.

The industry body further noted that Zomato and Swiggy exploited data derived from restaurant partners while launching competing products, creating a conflict of interest.

Daryani affirmed that the NRAI is â€œabsolutely not okayâ€ with this development, declaring the industry body would seek legal remedies while approaching regulatory authorities.

With the restaurant industry valued at Rs 5.69 lakh crore, the NRAI has urged restaurants, customers and regulators to work together and maintain ethical practices in the competitive food delivery space.

posts.name:
Pratyay Banerjee
Pratyay Banerjee
posts.content: TaskUs TaskUs (formerly heloo powered by TaskUs) Indoor has laid off more than 300 employees, leaving hundreds of families in distress. This decision highlights a disturbing trend where profits are prioritized over people. Employees are the backbone of any organization, and treating them as expendable undermines their immense contribution to a companyâ€™s success. Did the management consider the families who depend on these employees? In a country like India, where social security is minimal, such actions leave people vulnerable, with no safety net to fall back on. The government must step in immediately to address this issue and hold companies accountable for the well-being of their workforce. Organizations must realize that their true strength lies in their employees, not just in profits. It's time to put people first.

posts.name:
Dr. Manan Vora
Dr. Manan Vora
posts.content:
If you ended 2024 with unclaimed office leaves, youâ€™re endangering your mental health.

See, there are 2 kinds of employees.

1. Those who take advantage of every leave in their HR policy (this is 90% of people).

2. Those who think theyâ€™ll impress their boss and take as few leaves as possible.

If youâ€™re in the 2nd category, Iâ€™m here to tell you that youâ€™re doing it all wrong.

Firstly, most Indian companies give the bare minimum leave allowance - the least you need for your mental health.

And skipping even those leaves doesnâ€™t make you a better employee. It makes you a more exhausted one.

As a doctor, Iâ€™ve seen how chronic stress manifests in patients:

- Insomnia
- Fatigue
- Burnout

The human body isnâ€™t designed for constant output.

And mental reset grants you superpowers like:

- 40% more creativity
- A stronger immune system
- Higher emotional resilience
- And a higher life expectancy

So please, donâ€™t make the same mistake in 2025.

Block those leaves. Plan a trip. Or just stay home and sleep in.

Because when you take care of yourself, youâ€™re not â€˜slacking offâ€™ â€” youâ€™re investing in your long-term health, happiness, AND productivity.

So itâ€™s good for your mind, body and career.

Found this impactful? Repost to help your connections too.

make (and only 10% catch in time) is data leakage.

ğƒğšğ­ğš ğ¥ğğšğ¤ğšğ ğ ğ­ğ²ğ©ğ¢ğœğšğ¥ğ¥ğ² ğ¨ğœğœğ®ğ«ğ¬ ğğ®ğ ğ­ğ¨:
â†³ Copy-pasting code without understanding it
â†³ Scaling features before splitting the data
â†³ Including target variables in the feature set
â†³ Using future data in feature engineering
â†³ Shuffling data in time series cross-validation
â†³ Imputing missing values with data from the future

... and the list can go on.

Almost every data scientist has fallen into this trap at some point.

However, detecting data leakage early is a crucial skill to avoid disastrous outcomes.

ğ‡ğğ«ğ ğšğ«ğ ğš ğŸğğ° ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ§ğ¬ ğ¨ğŸ ğğšğ­ğš ğ¥ğğšğ¤ğšğ ğ:

â†³ If your data science lead points it out (seriously, this happens more often than you'd think!)

posts.name:
Sai Ram Somanaboina
Sai Ram Somanaboina
posts.content:
I donâ€™t hire developers by looking at how green their GitHub graph is and hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

A greener GitHub contribution graph doesnâ€™t mean higher skills or deeper expertise.

Let me tell you why:

1. Many teams use private repositories like Bitbucket or internal tools. Everything is mostly private. If they could show those commits, their graph would be green every day.

2. Students and junior developers often use GitHub to showcase their projects, challenges, or learning milestones.

Thatâ€™s great, but it doesnâ€™t automatically mean theyâ€™re â€œbetterâ€ than someone with a gray graph whoâ€™s been solving real-world problems for years.

3. git commits can be backdated or faked. A few commands and your GitHub can look like youâ€™ve been coding non-stop for years. Does that show skill? No.

4.A graph wonâ€™t tell me how you debug tough issues, work with a team, or handle edge cases in production.

What actually matters to me?

- Your problem-solving skills. Can you write clean, maintainable, and scalable code?
- Your mindset. Are you curious and eager to learn?
- Your collaboration. Can you work with others to build great software?
- Your impact. Do you understand the "why" behind what you're building?

Green graphs are cool to look at, but theyâ€™re not the full story.

And developers, if your GitHub isnâ€™t â€œgreen enough,â€ donâ€™t let that hold you back.

Focus on building great things, public or private.

What do you think? Do green graphs matter in hiring? Let me know below!
